data.text: Contents
Introduction

The Trust is committed to the positive identification of patients which when followed minimises the risk of patient misidentification. The application of patient identification bands is an essential part of the care process and should start at the beginning of a care episode and continues at each patient intervention throughout the patient's entire admission.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
2.1.1 Facilitate the accurate identification of patients, minimising the risk of patient harm as a result of misidentification; and
2.1.2 Ensure the right patient gets the right treatment / intervention / care first time, every time.
2.1.3 Ensure that any patient with a known allergy has a red band placed.
2.1.4 For information relating to identification of the newborn, refer to the guideline entitled ‘Attachment and Detachment of Identification Labels for the Newborn'; register number
This policy applies to:
2.2.1 All staff responsible for the care, treatment and identification of patients

2.2.2 This procedure provides information to staff on the correct identification of patients and all clinical staff can undertake this procedure. If a student is undertaking this procedure then the ID band will be double checked by a registered nurse / midwife.

2.2.3 All patients whether they are admitted as an inpatient, attending as an out-patient or emergency patient (including those waiting in the trolley areas of the Emergency Department undergoing assessment and investigations prior to admission) or are a newborn.

2.2.4 Detailed processes for checking patient's identity prior to operative procedures and the management of patients in the anaesthetic room can be found on the WHO Checklist and associated Local Safety Standards Invasive Procedures (LocSSIPs).
Exceptions to the policy are:

2.3.1 Life threatening situations in the Emergency Department, where immediate clinical care overrides the priority of patient identification. However, when the patient's condition stabilises, this procedure must be followed.

2.3.2 Clinical  condition  or  treatment  which  prevents  the  wearing  of  ID  bands  e.g. intravenous access lines, dermatology conditions and treatment and allergy to the materials used in the ID band.
2.3.3 Refusal to wear a ID band despite clear explanation of the risks of not doing so
Definitions

Integrated communication environment (Pathology results requesting/reporting system)

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Role and responsibilities within the Trust (Committees) Duties Are:
4.1.1 Information Governance Steering Group will receive reports of incidents relating to mis-identification and be responsible for ensuring the actions are completed.
4.1.2 The Heads of Nursing Groups are responsible for ensuring the patient identification policy is reviewed and updated.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust Duties Are:

4.2.1 The Chief Executive: has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has the necessary management systems in place to enable the effective implementation of this policy and overall responsibility for the health and safety of staff, patients and visitors
4.2.2 The  Managing  Director  will  ensure  that  safe  systems  are  in  place  to  allow implementation of this policy.
4.2.3 Clinical  Directors,  Heads  of  Nursing  /  Midwifery  and  Department  leads  are responsible for ensuring that this policy is adhered to and compliance with the requirements are monitored
Matrons and Ward Managers are responsible for:
4.3.1 Ensuring that staff in their areas are aware of and understand the policy and that it is implemented into practice locally
4.3.2 Ensuring  that  failures  to  comply  with  the  policy  are  reported  via  the  incident reporting system and the appropriate action is taken to prevent a recurrence.
4.3.3 Investigating failures to comply with the policy and ensure corrective action is taken to prevent a recurrence.
Clinical and non-clinical staff are responsible for:
4.4.1 Adhering to the standards in this policy and accepting accountability for their practice
4.4.2 Reporting all failures to comply with the policy via the incident reporting system
4.4.3 Ensuring that patients are identified using accurate personal details.
4.4.4 Ensuring that all patient details entered by them onto electronic or hardcopy records or ID bands are valid and accurate.

4.4.5 Ensuring that where an ID band is removed, it is replaced immediately and that the information on the replacement ID band is valid and accurate. If immediate replacement is not possible then it is the responsibility of the member of staff to make clear alternative arrangements for the patient's correct identification
4.4.6 Any member of staff discovering a patient without an ID band should assume responsibility for correctly identifying the patient and applying an ID band.

4.4.7 Primarily, it will be either nursing or midwifery staff, or support staff who will be responsible for the generation and application of the patient's ID band. However, it is the responsibility of all staff to check the validity and accuracy of patient identification before carrying out any actions relating to patient care.

4.4.8 The use of ID bands does not remove the individual clinician's responsibility for checking patient identity before administering medication or treatment, in line with existing policies including consent policies, blood transfusion policies and administration of medicine policies.
Directorate Governance Leads are responsible for:
4.5.1 investigating patient identification incidents, identifying training needs and assessing risks
4.5.2 Sharing lessons learned through the Information Governance Committee
4.5.3 IT Department is responsible for:
4.5.4 Sourcing, purchasing, setting up and maintaining the printers for ID bands
4.5.5 Ensuring that the ward staff have the appropriate training to use the equipment provided for them
4.5.6 Ensuring that the IT reporting systems are updated appropriately to enable continued use of the printers within the clinical areas
4.5.7 Ensuring that the IT systems have the available updates applied to them as and when they become available from the supplier.
Patient Identification Procedure
Patient Identification

5.1.1 Accurate patient identification starts with the patient's first contact with the service and it is the responsibility of all staff involved in the admission, clinical and administrative processes to ensure correct details are obtained and recorded and that any inaccuracies or queries are highlighted and dealt with.

5.1.2 It is essential that patients are registered on the Trust's patient administration system (such as Lorenzo or Medway PAS) or other appropriate clinical systems, and wherever possible checks must be made as to ensure that the person is not already registered to avoid duplicate registration and the risks associated with duplicated records.
5.1.3 On each admission / attendance, the patient details must be re-checked.

5.1.4 If pre-printed patient identity labels are used, these must be checked and re- printed for every admission and placed in the front of the medical records, ensuring disposal of the previous front sheet and any out of date patient identity labels.
5.1.5 As a minimum staff must check the patient's:
Name (surname and first name);
Date of birth;
Address;
GP;
Next of kin.

5.1.6 When checking patient identity, the patient/parent/guardian must be asked to verbalise the details. Patients must not be allowed to agree passively with what staff say. Therefore, the question must be ‘what is your full name?' rather than “Are you Mrs. Smith?”
5.1.7 If the patient is unable to respond due to their clinical condition or capacity, identification should be verified with family or relatives wherever possible.
5.1.8 If the patient is unable to state their name, then the ID band must be checked by two members of staff, with the health records available, to ensure all details match.

5.1.9 When initially identifying a patient, there may be a language difficulty in communicating with the patient. In this situation support from an interpreter / interpreting service may be used to assist. This requirement should be recorded in the healthcare record.
5.1.10 Particular care must be taken for patients with common names i.e. Mary Smith and in instances where there are patients with the same or similar names simultaneously in a clinical area.

5.1.11 The patient's NHS number can be obtained during the registration process on the patient information system when the patient's record is synchronised with the national Personal Demographic Service (PDS). All users who have the relevant role based access control rights to register patients have access to this functionality.

5.1.12 If the patient confirms that the details held in their patient administration records is incorrect it is essential that this is updated immediately. A new ID band must be produced using the updated information.
The unconscious patient

5.2.1 Patients can be unconscious for a number of reasons. Sometimes it is the treatment they are having e.g. anaesthetic/sedation, but it may be due to the influence of drugs or alcohol. Where patients are incapable of identifying themselves and maintaining their own safety it is the responsibility of the staff looking after the patient to ensure they can be identified properly. The temporary identification for unknown or unidentified patients must be carried out in accordance with the patient safety alert NHS/PSA/RE/2018/008

5.2.2 Staff must provide a unique identifier for the patient until such time as their identity is established. This number should be used for all procedures and interventions to identify the patient. The senior staff responsible for the patient's care will ensure that all records are merged when the patient's identity is established. The patient ID band must contain the following information:
5.2.3 For names, a distinctive method is used to randomly generate combinations of first and surname from an edited phonetic alphabet e.g Foxtrot Whisky.
5.2.4 Unit number - A random generated seven digit number will be generated with the
relevant standard NHS Trust code
5.2.5 Date of Birth – 1st January will be combined with the patient's estimated year of birth, e.g 01/01/1950
5.2.6 All unconscious patients must wear an ID band for identification purposes except
in life threatening situations in the Emergency Department, where immediate
clinical care overrides the priority of patient identification (see section 2.3).

5.2.7 In the extreme event that an unconscious patient is transferred from the Emergency Department to another clinical area for urgent treatment without an ID band in situ, the Registered Professional in charge of the patient's care should travel with the patient to provide positive identification prior to any investigation or treatment being undertaken. ID bands should then be applied at the first available opportunity.
Patient identification bands
5.3.1 Who may apply the ID band:
Registered Nurses and Midwives;
Medical Staff;
Allied Healthcare Professionals;
Healthcare Support Workers;
Student Nurses / Student Midwives under the supervision of a Registered Nurse or Midwife.

5.3.2 Patients must be given a clear explanation of the importance of wearing an identification band for their own safety at all times during their hospital stay or outpatient attendance and their consent gained.

5.3.2 If the patient is confused or unable to respond, the same explanation should be given to the relative/carer so that they are made aware. In the absence of a patient representative who knows them well, the identity bands of patients who cannot confirm their own identity (e.g. those who cannot communicate, young children, the critically ill, unconscious, or confused) must be checked by two Registered Nurses/Midwives prior to the identity band being placed on the patient.
5.3.3 All inpatients, adult or child (excluding neonates) MUST be provided with and wear at least one white patient identification bands on admission.

5.3.4 No procedures can take place without and ID band, except excluded patients (see sections 2.3). Where there is a reason for a patient not to wear an identity band e.g. skin irritation, this must be documented in the clinical records, stating the alternative methods of identification implemented e.g. details pinned to clothing.

5.3.5 The ID band may be applied to the ankles when there is a risk of compromised patient safety e.g. frequent checking during surgery, for patient with very small wrists for whom the size of the red visible part of the band may be compromised or patients who are cognitively impaired. In this instance the position of the ID band should be documented in the patient's healthcare record.

5.3.6 The patient ID band shall be applied to be comfortable but secure enough that it cannot be removed by the patient. If the patient's limbs are too large, then 2 patient ID bands may be joined together.

5.3.7 Any patient undergoing major surgery or trauma that necessitates the insertion of multiple intravenous cannulae, or arterial lines OR any upper limb surgery must have identity bands applied to unaffected limbs only. In some cases, such as in critical care or theatres, due to the presence of arterial lines, multiple peripheral lines and oedematous limbs, staff may need to join ID bands together ensuring patient identity is maintained at all times.
5.3.8 During emergency or operative procedure, if ID bands need to be removed from the limbs the ID band must be applied to the patients skin using see-through plastic adhesive film.

5.3.9 When an internal transfer occurs, the receiving staff member should check the patient ID band with the patient where the patient has the capacity to do so, along with the medical notes, for positive patient identification.

5.3.10 ID bands must be replaced when a patient is transferred and the new ward location stated on the ID band. Patients who are transferring in from other hospitals will have the relevant hospital ID band applied immediately on arrival and the ID band from the transferring hospital removed.

5.3.11 The positive patient identification process should include asking the patient if they have any allergies that staff need to be aware of. If the patient has a known allergy red identification bands must be used instead of the white identification bands. Patients requiring special blood products such as irradiated blood must be issued with a RED wrist band identifying the products required before the transfusion is commenced.
Emergency Department
5.4.1 In the Emergency Department setting there are patients where patient ID band must be applied; these are as follows:

5.4.2 All patients who are streamed to Emergency Services Assessment Team (ESAT) or equivalent, Majors and Resus (or awaiting movement to these stream areas in the ambulance bay) must have an ID band in situ; this should be printed through following Triage. If an allergy is identified a separate allergy band should also be attached at this point
5.4.3 Ambulatory / minor streamed patients where it is professionally judged to be appropriate, for example for patients who lack capacity, or who are having procedural sedation/blocks
5.4.4 All ED/acute medicine patients attending for a radiological investigation on a trolley or a bed and all patients who lack capacity.
5.4.5 All patients where a decision to admit has been made.
Generating ID Bands

5.5.1 The information on the patient ID band will be checked with the patient /carer/ relative and health record immediately prior to application and wherever possible the ID band will be printed and applied to the patient at the bedside.
5.5.2 It is the responsibility of the person who generates the patient identification band to ensure that this contains the correct patient details and that the patient wears their band correctly.
5.5.3 It is not acceptable for pre-printed labels (addressograph labels) to be used on ID bands.
5.5.4 The following information must be clearly printed in black ink on all adult and child (excluding unwell neonates) white and red identification bands.

table_items.text: Before first name and in upper case
Same line as surname and in lower case
In day, month and year order
The number on the main clinical records not departmental numbers

data.text: Maternity, neonates and nursing mothers
5.6.1 On admission to the maternity unit, all mothers will have a printed identity band applied.

5.6.2 Once the baby(s) has been born, two white identification bands will be printed or written (for each baby), and one applied to each ankle. The ID bands will be checked with the mother or father and her birthing partner before being applied to the baby's ankle.
5.6.3 The following information must be clearly printed in black ink on all newborn / neonate identification bands

table_items.text: First name and Surname of mother
Before first name and in upper case Must correspond to the mothers For multiple deliveries, the birth order (i.e TWIN / TRIPLET I, II or III) should be added after the surname
In day, month and year order
Newborn/neonates NHS or local hospital number or Mothers NHS Number or Unit Number
Unwell neonates will be issued with a Unit number on arrival in Neonate Unit. The number on the main medical records

data.text: 5.6.4 The following information must be clearly printed in black ink on all newborn / neonate cot labels:

table_items.text: Newborn/neonates unit number or Mothers NHS Number Or Unit Number

data.text: 5.6.5 On warding on the postnatal ward both identification labels should be checked to ensure that they are present and also to verify that the baby has been labelled correctly with the mother's details.

5.6.6 Two identification labels should remain on the infant until discharged and the infant must  leave  the  hospital  wearing  the  ID  labels  to  ensure  the  correct  baby  is discharged with the correct mother.
5.6.7 All ID bands will be checked every day during the daily examination to ensure that there arein place and that the details are correct. If one is lost then this will be replaced immediately.
5.6.8 If both ID bands are lost the following steps are to be completed:
Inform the midwife in charge of the shift;
Check every other baby's ID band on the ward before replacing the ID band. This procedure can be conducted by a Midwife and MCA;
Complete an incident form;

If all other babies on the ward are correctly labelled then two new labels should be completed and the details checked with the mother before attaching securely to ensure the correct baby is with the correct mother.
5.6.9 If two or more babies do not have ID bands, confirm the following information with the mothers and maternity system birth details:
Does the mother have ID bands;
Date / time and method of delivery;
Gender;
Ethnicity;
Birth weight;
Presence of ‘cot card';
Ward bay / room transferred to;
Has baby been roomed in with mother.

5.6.10 Apply the ID bands once the ID has been confirmed, a cot card with printed label and barcode should be made available and an incident form completed. If we cannot determine the identity of the babies, this may be declared as a potential serious incident and DNA screening may be required.
5.6.11 When a nursing mother is admitted and brings her baby with her, the infant must be identified with two white hand written identification bands which must include:
Mothers last name;
Baby's name;
Date of birth.
Identification of babies in the Neonatal Unit

5.7.1 Patient ID bands are to be used to identify babies in NICU. However, it may not always be possible in some cases due to the medical condition of the baby e.g. skin fragility, insertion of long lines or multiple peripheral lines.
5.7.2 It is recognised that babies are not taken away from their incubators, therefore the use of name cards on the incubator would be considered a means of identifying the baby.
5.7.3 However, the nurse should regularly assess the baby to decide when to use an identification band, as the baby's condition allows.
5.7.4 Care should be taken if babies are moved from one clinical space to another e.g. ITU to HDU and that the correct healthcare records follow the baby and incubator.
5.7.5 When the identification band is not on the baby:
The incubator cot must have an identification band or name card taped to the outside with the baby's correct details, this will be used as means of identifying the baby;
Nursing notes are kept with the incubator or cot;
Nursing staff ensure the correct notes are with the correct baby;
A one to one handover at the change of shift with baby's notes present should be undertaken.
Patients unable to wear or Declining to Wear Identification Bands

5.8.1 Occasionally, some patients are unable to wear identification bands, because of their clinical condition or treatment. In addition some patients may refuse to wear an identification band for a variety of reasons. If such a situation arises it is important that staff assess and manage the associated risks for the correct identification of the patient.

5.8.2 If patients refuse or are unable to wear identification, staff must be even more vigilant in ensuring that the correct patient is identified prior to any procedure, intervention or treatment. Staff must ask the patient to identify themselves by stating their:
Full name;
Address;
Date of birth.
5.8.3 Where a patient is incapable of identifying themselves, verification of identity should be made by asking the carer or relative and checking the patient's medical records.

5.8.4 If a patient is unable to wear an identification band due to clinical condition or treatment all staff participating in treatment/care delivery must be notified. Reasons should be clearly documented in the patients' clinical records and alternative methods of identification agreed and documented.

5.8.5 Where the patient refuses to wear an identification band, a risk assessment should be undertaken and the potential risks associated with incorrect identification must be communicated to the patient. The Medical and Nursing staff responsible for care, treatment delivery must be informed of the patient's refusal to wear identification bands and documented in the clinical records and an incident form completed.
Out-Patient Clinics

5.9.1 In the Outpatient clinic setting, it is not normally necessary for patients to wear ID bands as verification of the patient identity will be made by reception staff when the patient arrives and books onto the clinic (exceptions detailed below). Reception staff will ask the patient or their carer/relative to state:
Full name (surname and first name);
Date of birth;
Address.
5.9.2 Where patients use the In-touch, self-booking system, then OPD clinical staff should validate patient information directly with them.

5.9.3 The reception staff will be responsible for validating the information given by the patient and/or their carer/relative with the Trust's patient information system, the patient's notes (when available) and, where necessary their appointment card or letter.

5.9.4 When patients are called for their appointment, the clinical nurse or reviewing doctor must confirm the identity of the patient by asking open questions to the patients or their carer. For example, ‘please tell me your name' rather than ‘Are you Mrs Smith?' This identification check must include confirmation of three patient identifiers as stated above.

5.9.5 There are exceptions where an outpatient must wear an ID band such as those patients who are attending an outpatient department to undergo therapy or procedures. ID bands may be applied in the Outpatient Department if clinical staff perceives there is a risk of mistaken identity and feel that it is expedient to do so.

5.9.6 Patients who return for regular assessment of anti-coagulant therapy must have their full details checked against the Trust patient information system, their patient notes and therapy card and the specimen request form and specimen bottle before the sample is obtained.
Contingency Plan in case of IT system failure, electrical shutdown or disruption to the power supply

5.10.1 In the case of system failure, planned electricity shutdown or disruption to the power supply, the admitting person or in the case of newborns, the midwife must apply handwritten identity bands to the appropriate limbs of the patient. The bands must contain the information as stated above in sections 5.5 and 5.6 and be written in black ink.

5.10.2 The wards will all have a supply of ID bands that can be handwritten. These will be stored in the emergency ‘grab box' and are to be used as a contingency arrangement only. All areas will be responsible for replenishing stocks used
Removal of ID bands
5.11.1 Ideally the ID band must not be removed until the discharge procedure is completed and the patient leaves the ward/department or clinical area. Exceptions to this practice are given below.

5.11.2 Where it is necessary to remove a patient's ID band, for whatever reason, it is the responsibility of the member of staff removing the ID band to ensure that it is replaced immediately on an alternative limb. If this is not possible, then they are responsible for making sure the reason for removal is documented in the patient's notes and alternative means of identification specified.
Checking patient identity prior to care and treatment

5.12.1 It is critical that all staff acknowledge that the management and monitoring of patient identification is an ongoing process. Staff must always check patient details to be sure that they are dealing with the right person, clerical staff should always validate the information given by the patient with the information held on the Trust's records (hard copy and electronic).

5.12.2 Clinical staff must always validate that the verbal identification given by the patient (or their relatives) matches the information on the patient's ID band before carrying out any procedure, administering any prescribed medications including chemotherapy, instigating examinations, investigations or treatments as appropriate including blood transfusion. This must happen even if you think you know the patient well. If no ID band is present then this must be replaced immediately unless exceptions apply (see section 2.3)
5.12.3 Do not use the names above patient's beds as a method of identification as the patient may be sitting in the wrong place or names above the bed not changed.
5.12.4 Do not perform two tasks at the same time that require patient identification (e/g intravenous drugs and venepuncture).

5.12.5 No in-patient is to be examined or receive treatment in the absence of an identification band except in extreme emergencies (see section 2.3), the presence of the ID band should be checked before patients are sent for examination or treatment. Before carrying out an investigation on inpatients, ask the patient their details and check this with the patient ID band and the information on the investigations / request form. For excluded patients without an ID band, document on the investigation / request form the name of the ward person confirming the identity of the patient.
5.12.6 When a patient is to be admitted to Theatres it is the responsibility of the member of staff receiving the patient to check the patient's identity with:
The nurse transferring the patient to theatre;
The patient (where possible);
The patient's notes (name and identifying number) to verify that the patient has been correctly identified.

5.12.7 For outpatients, on presenting in the consulting room the clinician must confirm the identity of the patient by asking them (or their carer) to state the patient's full name and date of birth as described in section 5.1.

5.12.8 Before carrying out an investigation on outpatients, ask the patient (or relative carer if they are unable to do so) to confirm their details and check this with the patient information system / clinical record prior to commencing any investigations or treatment
5.12.9 Patient's identity must be checked prior to porters or other non-ward based staff moving the patient out of the ward/unit:
Establish name of patient to be moved by porter slip or teletracking information
Check the identification of the patient with the named nurse by checking the ID band. If no ID band in situ this must be placed onto the patient immediately, prior to leaving the ward/unit
Ensure healthcare records accompany patient as appropriate if attending for an investigation/examination within another department to ensure correct ID process can be carried out
5.12.10 The legibility of the information on the ID band should be checked each time the patient identification is required and the ID band should be changed as soon as illegibility is noted.
5.12.11 If any discrepancy is found, do not undertake the operation, treatment or procedure until the discrepancy is rectified.
Investigation / request forms
5.13.1 Patient details documented on investigation/request forms must originate from the relevant patient information system or patient ID band
5.13.2 Where sufficient information is known, all sections of investigation forms must be completed and be legible

5.13.3 Where insufficient information is known, to minimise the risk of conflicting information and subsequent rejection of the request, a minimum of three of the following patient identifiers must be present on the form:
NHS / Unit number;
First and last name;
Date of birth;
Genito-Urinary medicine reference number;
A/E number;
Unknown male/female in conjunction only with A/E number.

5.13.4 If the report destination, requesting clinician's signature and required analysis is not on the form, the request may be rejected leading to unnecessary discomfort to the patient and delay in treatment when the sample is repeated.
Sample collection

5.14.1 Blood sample collection must be undertaken in accordance with blood transfusion policies. The labelling criteria for these samples is very strict and all four unique patient identifiers must be written on the tube and signed by the person taking the blood sample. These include Hospital number / NHS number (outside the Trust), First name, Surname and date of birth. Sample must be dates and forms must be dated and timed.
5.14.2 Where possible patients should be asked to confirm their identity as described above

5.14.3 The patient details on the investigation/request form should be checked with those on the patient ID band before taking the sample and verbally checked with the patient to confirm their identity.
Specimen labelling
5.15.1 Labelling must take place immediately after the specimen has been obtained and before leaving the patient (at the bedside).

5.15.2 Labels must be completed clearly with as many of the relevant key identifiers stated above as possible. However, where all information is unavailable a sample will be accepted with a minimum of patient's full name, date of birth and hospital number. N.B Sample date must be recorded but this is not a patient identifier.
5.15.3 Pre-printed labels (e.g PAS labels) will not be accepted as a method of identifying samples except those from the Emergency Department (except blood transfusion samples).

5.15.4 Samples must be dated and signed. Note that all transfusion samples must contain the collector's signature. Cellular pathology samples that do not meet these requirements must be verified by a senior clinician
Misidentification
5.16.1 Where patient misidentification occurs, the patient's true identity must be established in accordance with the core patient identification information.

5.16.2 If an error occurs, for example a patient receives the wrong medication; or the wrong investigation or procedures are carried out; or an incorrect result is reported; all appropriate actions must be initiated to resolve the error. Treatment, medications or blood transfusion must be stopped immediately and the appropriate treatment given.

5.16.3 The person who identifies this event must advise the appropriate Doctor and/or Nurse in Charge and document in the patient healthcare records including any actions necessary to minimise the risk to the patient.

5.16.4 Where investigations have been commenced/completed the Doctor must be notified to decide whether these are to be repeated and whether the relevant department (pathology, radiology etc) needs to be notified.
5.16.5 In the case of blood transfusion errors, the doctor, laboratory and blood transfusion nurse (or equivalent) must be informed as soon as possible in line with blood transfusion policies.
5.16.6 Where this occurs outside of the in-patient area the department must notify the ward an error has been discovered.
5.16.7 An incident form must be completed in all cases of misidentification, in accordance with the procedure for the reporting and management of incidents and serious incidents.
5.16.8 Where misidentification has led to a clinical incident, the patient/relative/carer must be advised in accordance with the Trusts being open policy.
5.16.1 Where patient misidentification occurs, the patient's true identity must be established in accordance with the core patient identification information.

5.16.2 If an error occurs, for example a patient receives the wrong medication; or the wrong investigation or procedures are carried out; or an incorrect result is reported; all appropriate actions must be initiated to resolve the error. Treatment, medications or blood transfusion must be stopped immediately and the appropriate treatment given.

5.16.3 The person who identifies this event must advise the appropriate Doctor and/or Nurse in Charge and document in the patient healthcare records including any actions necessary to minimise the risk to the patient.

5.16.4 Where investigations have been commenced/completed the Doctor must be notified to decide whether these are to be repeated and whether the relevant department (pathology, radiology etc) needs to be notified.
5.16.5 In the case of blood transfusion errors, the doctor, laboratory and blood transfusion nurse (or equivalent) must be informed as soon as possible in line with blood transfusion policies.
5.16.6 Where this occurs outside of the in-patient area the department must notify the ward an error has been discovered.
5.16.7 An incident form must be completed in all cases of misidentification, in accordance with the procedure for the reporting and management of incidents and serious incidents.
5.16.8 Where misidentification has led to a clinical incident, the patient/relative/carer must be advised in accordance with the Trusts being open policy
Training requirements
The Trust is committed to ensuring that a policy and guideline is available to staff to inform them of correct safe patient identification management.

The Trust recognises its responsibility to ensure that staff are appropriately educated and trained to participate effectively in patient identification. To support this both clinical and non-clinical staff will receive an induction programme from the ward or department manager that will ensure all staff are trained on the appropriate patient identification procedures and IT systems.

Staff taking blood samples, collecting and / or administering blood products will receive relevant training on patient identification as part of these procedures in accordance with blood transfusion policies.
Monitoring and audit
All incidents where there is failure to adhere to the requirements of this policy will be reported via the incident reporting system.
Inpatient ID bands are monitored monthly via the nursing audits (e.g. principles of care audits and dashboard audits). Ten sets of notes are reviewed along with patient ID bands being checked.
